fields.subtitle: Also called "classifier
fields.text: In chinese, to say "one apple", you must say "one" + mesure word + "apple". There are a lot of mesure words used for different types of things. "Gè" is the most common and it is used for apples, for exemple.
It can be used in connection with 要 (yào) to indicate a changement of state in the future. In expressions about time, it can be used in connection with 就要 (jiùyào).

fields.subtitle: Used for small numbers
fields.text: It can be used as an interrogative pronoun ("how many?"), or to indicate an indetermined quantity ("several")

fields.meaning: Call, be called, ask to do

fields.text: This particle is used to send back a question, to ask about a location, to indicate that an action is in progress, to soften a question, to stress a rethorical question, or to emphasize an exageration.
As an interrogative pronoun, it can be used before an adjective to ask about the intensity; for exemple: 多高? (duō gāo?, how tall is he?).
It is a "mesure word" so it doesn't need a mesure word before it.

This particle can be put in the middle of 2 nouns to connect them: the first noun is the owner of the second noun. The particle can also connect an adjective and a noun that posses the quality indicated by the adjective. When it is already clear who is the owner or the noun that posses the quality, the owner and the noun can be omitted. It can be used also to form sentences that act as a complement of a noun.
It can be used in connection with 了 (le) to mean "already".

fields.subtitle: Starting point
fields.text: This preposition is used to indicate a starting point and express a distance in time, space, or to a goal.Often used in connection with 到 (to, dào)
As a verb, the meaning is "may". When the meaning is "probably", it is always placed before the subject of before the verb.

fields.subtitle: Time adverb
fields.text: This time adverb is used to stress the time of an action.

fields.subtitle: Effect, degree, possibility
fields.text: Structural particle: used after a verb (or adjective as main verb), linking it to following phrase indicating effect, degree, possibility etc;
The most common way to form a superlative (like best, worst, biggest, smallest, etc.) in Chinese is to use 最 (zuì) before an adjective (and a few select verbs).

fields.subtitle: Number of times
fields.text: It is used after a number and before the ver. There are 2 exception: 1) when it is used in connection with a place, it is put after the place; 2) when it is use in connection with a pronoun, it is put after the pronoun.
Exemples: 每天 (měi tiān, every day), 每年 (měi nián, every year),  每个月 (měi yuè, every month), 每个星期 (měi xīngqí, every week).
It can bu put before and adjective to set an exclamatory mood, for exemple: 你真好 (nǐ zhēn hǎo, you are really nice)
after a verb to indicate an action is in a progress or in a certain state that continues
To express the distance from a place a moment in time, or a purpose. Often used together with 近 (jìn, close) and 远 (yuǎn, far).

fields.subtitle: Express a desire
fields.text: When used before a verb, it indicates the desire to do something. The negative form is 不想 (bù xiǎng)

fields.subtitle: Completion or a past state
fields.text: Particle used after a verb as a complement, indicating completion or a past state

fields.meaning: Not so..., a little less than...
fields.text: Used before an adjective, this adverb moderate adjectives or verbs.
It is placed after the noun, for exemple 桌子 下面 (zhuōzi xiàmiàn, under the desk)

fields.subtitle: Used after a verb
fields.text: To perform an action just for a little time, or to soften an order.
Used to ask a question when you already know the answer, frequently used at the beginning or end of a sentence, but it can also be used in the middle in same cases.
It is a "mesure word" so it doesn't need a mesure word before it.
Used to make a conclusion
Used before an adjective to complain
Used at the end of a sentence it invites to exlude the opposit of what has been said. It can also be used to make a comparaison denying the identity.

fields.subtitle: To express ordinal numbers
fields.text: This particle must be put before a number to form an ordinal number.

fields.subtitle: Expressing a prohibition
fields.text: If it is used in connection with the particle 了 (le), it means "stop doing".

fields.subtitle: Negative imperative particle
fields.text: If it is used in connection with the particle 了 (le), it means "stop doing".

fields.subtitle: Comparative particle
fields.text: This particle is used to compare things. It can be used in connection with an expression that states the grade of the difference beetween the compared elements.
It can be used in connection with 比 (bǐ) to express the grade of the comparaison.

fields.subtitle: To express a contrasting premise
fields.text: It introduces a premise that contrasts with the conclusion, in connection with 但是 (dàn shì) which introduces the conclusion.

fields.subtitle: To express a contrasting conlusion
fields.text: It introduces a conclusion that contrasts with the premise, in connection with 虽然 (suī rán ) which introduces the premise.
